I bow to the sun-like wondrous wisdom, which shines its light to break the darkness and open the pure eye,
Distributing the subtle words of the Treatise in One Hundred Verses far and wide, I shall explain it as the hundred sages practice it.
The treatise says:

In order to show that the self and its belongings grasped by wrong views are all empty in nature and characteristics, [the treatise] skillfully reveals the three gates of liberation, and thus this treatise is composed.

Because grasping the nature of perceived objects as a skillful means, one gives rise to discrimination of characteristics. Following the grasping of the characteristics of perceived objects as a basis, one gives rise to wrong aspirations and enjoyments. Since the emptiness of perceived objects is shown, the two [i.e., discrimination and wrong aspirations/enjoyments] are then non-existent.
The perceived objects of its belongings are roughly of two kinds, namely, permanent and impermanent.
The superior, tranquil, and blissful state of permanent abiding - when sentient beings hear of the bliss, peace, and effortless nature of this state, they often give rise to delight and joy.
Impermanent things are inferior and can lead to suffering. Sentient beings, seeing suffering like being burned by a raging fire, often give rise to aversion.
Therefore, the treatise first refutes permanent things.
Thus, a verse says:ğŸ”½All things arise as effects,
Therefore they have impermanent natures;ğŸ”½Thus, except for the Buddha, there is no one
Who can be called a TathÄgata in reality.
The treatise states:

The various worldly contemptible doctrines and the various meanings of permanence spoken by others often go beyond the scope of direct perception, being established by inference through their ability to produce effects.
Since they can produce effects, they should also be inferred to arise from conditions, like gross forms and so forth.
If they do not arise from conditions, lacking superior substance and function, they should be unable to produce, like space flowers and so forth.
If it is accepted that their meaning arises from conditions, then they would definitely be destroyed, like the effects that are produced.
Therefore, the Buddha said that all conditioned things are impermanent, arising and ceasing from conditions, like pleasure, pain, and so forth.
Therefore, only the Buddha's teachings are free from error, and he is called the TathÄgata because he sees all objects without obstruction.
If that is so, the other unproduced fruits and functions should be permanent, since they do not produce fruits, they cannot be inferred to arise from conditions.
Although that is so, since they lack the ability to produce fruits, they are like complete cessation and do not exist, as can be inferred.
In order to show that this statement is definitive in meaning, another verse is spoken:
There is no time, place, or substance that has a nature that is not produced from conditions;
Therefore, there is no time, place, or substance that has a nature and is permanent.
The treatise states:
All dharmas with a nature definitely arise from conditions, like suffering, happiness, and so forth.
If they are not produced from conditions, they definitely have no nature, like space flowers and so forth.
If this [unproduced dharma] has a nature, it should arise from conditions.
If it arises from conditions, cessation will definitely follow, and it cannot be allowed to abide permanently.
This has been explained.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Or, perhaps all dharmas are known to have a nature only when they definitely arise in dependence on conditions, like present dharmas.
If they do not arise in dependence on conditions, then they do not have a nature, like future dharmas.
In order to explain this meaning, the words time, place, etc. are spoken.
This shows that the principle being discussed is certain.
Whether in terms of time, place, or the distinctions of things, everywhere there is no dispute.
As it is said, The bodhisattva abides in the contemplation of dharmas, and in all dharmas he does not see a single dharma that goes beyond dependent arising.
Moreover, they earnestly apply their ingenuity to that which is impossible.
Why is this?
The verse says:
There is no nature without a cause.
The treatise says:
Although they earnestly apply their ingenuity to establish permanence, in the end they are unable to speak of any principle.
In this way, the meaning of the statement is that one part of the basis of the proof is not established.
Since they do not admit the existence of other similar meanings, the example lacks a common property, and the inference is not established.
Even if one were to forcibly speak of it, it would still be unreasonable.
Why is this?
The verse says:
If there is a cause, it is not permanent.
The commentary says:

Even if one were to forcibly speak of permanence having a cause, since it is admitted that there is a cause, it is not a permanent nature. Like the characteristics produced by a blazing fire of suffering, this cause can contradict the basis.
Although there is no cause of arising, there is a cause of existence. Because of the general existence of causes, it is established.
Furthermore, there is the grasping that all natures are permanent. If one establishes that all are impermanent, both lack a similar example, and the inference is not established.
This is also not so, because of the same error as before.

Moreover, although they establish the hidden nature as permanent, they establish that the manifest characteristics have arising and ceasing. Because of this, it is sufficient to manifest the nature of impermanence and refute the nature of permanence. Because that treatise refutes the manifest characteristics as being permanent and non-existent.
If it is said that the manifest characteristics also have no arising and ceasing, with no decrease in the previous state and no increase in the later state.
What is the purpose of the authors of treatises?
What do they create?
If it is said that although dharmas have concealment and manifestation, they have no arising and ceasing, this is also not so.
If there is no difference between the two periods of time before and after, then there is no increase or decrease. What concealment and manifestation are there?
Moreover, apart from the substance, there is no separate time. If time has concealment and manifestation, the substance should also be so.
Although you do not wish for the substance to have arising and ceasing, because of the pressure of reason, you must necessarily believe and accept it.

In this way, the established two periods of time, concealment and manifestation, are not permanent, serving as a similar example. Because of this, my establishment is not the same as yours, because the established permanent similar example definitely does not exist.
Moreover, the established meaning must have a cause. It cannot be established merely by giving rise to the mind.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Therefore, without a cause, wanting to establish true seeing is said to be non-existent.
The treatise says:
All inferences that can establish meanings not accepted by others are called valid.
If one departs from the correct reason and merely makes empty statements expressing one's own ideas, the meaning will ultimately not be established.
If it is said that meaning can be established without a reason, then everything that is established should be established.
Even if everything is established, what are you stingy about now?
I am also not stingy.
That is not established by itself.
Everything is established, but you also do not allow it.

Furthermore, some others one-sidedly adhere to the thesis that the sound of a treatise is permanent, not depending on conditions at the beginning, and without destruction later, naturally able to manifest and transcend the meaning of the faculties, as a definitive means of knowledge that has never been mistaken.

Means of knowledge such as perception and inference depend on the views of human beings, and human beings have errors. Views are causes of doubt, so the means of knowledge that they depend on are all difficult to believe and accept.
This is also not so, because it is not separate from the previously mentioned faults that are not loved.
If the person who relies on it and the views all have faults, and therefore the dependent valid cognitions also have errors, then since your views and statements have errors, how can they be trusted?
The words you speak will then become self-destructive.

If your intention is to say that the words spoken by you and your teacher are also definitive valid cognitions, while the other sounds are not, there is no inferential cognition, but only love for your own school, and you also contradict your own established thesis.

Moreover, using inferential cognition to establish that the sound of the treatise is not created by a person and its substance is eternal, the reason and similar example should be further established.
Even if you can establish them, it will be self-destructive.
Moreover, the sound of the treatise and the remaining sounds are the same in being the nature of sound. Why do you only say that this sound is eternal and the other sounds are impermanent?
It is also not acceptable to say that others themselves accept that sound is impermanent because it is created by a person, and therefore it is not eternal.
Now it is not accepted, and therefore it is eternal.
How can the nature of dharmas be determined by whether or not the proponent allows them to be permanent or impermanent?
It cannot be said that the nature of all dharmas changes according to the differences in views, because one thing simultaneously having multiple contradictory natures is unreasonable.
If a dharma changes according to people's subjective thoughts, then one should abandon one's own view and adopt the other's view.
Moreover, those who establish permanence only rely on dissimilar examples, because there are no similar examples, so what is established is not established, or one abandons one's own intention.
Therefore, their doctrine is not suitable for investigation, as it is only a fabrication of empty words, without any real meaning.
Next, there are others who assert:
Only dissimilar examples are called valid cognition, because they pervade dissimilar dharmas.
The original purpose of inference is to negate other meanings, because the characteristics of negation are seen to be able to manifest the meaning through mixed conditions.
In order to determine this meaning, it is further said:
Since all that is produced is impermanent, therefore it is known that what is not produced must be permanent.
This statement is meant to show a definite difference, but this is also unreasonable, because words that follow one's own intention cannot truly manifest the correct principle.
Why is this?

Only the meaning of difference that is negated in the object is called a similar example. The two parts of the different dharma example both occur and can be called universal. If there is no similar example, what is universal?
It cannot be said that the self-nature is universally present in itself.
Moreover, all inferential cognition that wishes to negate other meanings must have a similar dharma and then it can be established.
If the similar dharma does not exist, the different dharma should not exist either.
Because apart from the two aggregates of similarity and difference, no other category of meaning is admitted.
By this, the characteristics of negation that are directly perceived and mixed are destroyed, and the conditions that manifest the meaning are shown.
Moreover, using what is produced as the reason to prove that there is permanence, this is ultimately unreasonable, because in all cases it has never been seen to exist.
Therefore, a verse is spoken:
Seeing that what is produced is impermanent, what is not produced is considered to be permanent;
Since one sees that impermanence exists, one should say that the nature of permanence is non-existent.
The treatise says:
What is produced is all impermanent, what is not produced is all permanent.
Since one sees that the nature of impermanence exists in what is produced, one should say that the nature of permanence in what is not produced is non-existent.

Since what is produced is already admitted to have substance, what is not produced should be admitted to be without substance, because the non-producing cause has never been seen to exist in pleasure, etc., and the non-existence of tortoise hair, etc., can all be obtained.
In this way, what is not produced contradicts the self-nature that is the basis of the proof, and is not the correct proof, is it not so?
If the contradictory cause does not obstruct what is commonly accepted by oneself and others, then it can establish the contradiction of the self-nature distinctions in one's own domain.

Now, the basis of the dispute is generally accepted as existing. If it were not generally accepted, it would not be possible to dispute about its permanence or impermanence based on it. Therefore, the reason of being a product cannot be refuted by the self-nature of the basis.
Some explain:
We now do not accept that there are scattered atoms outside of aggregated atoms. Therefore, this reason of contradiction does not have the fault of self-refutation.

This explanation is not correct. They establish all permanent dharmas as existing based on general characteristics. How could they bother to distinguish whether aggregated or scattered [atoms] exist or not?
If this is the explanation, then space and the other unconditioned dharmas are not accepted at all, and cannot be criticized.
Although atoms of form, etc. are accepted as existing based on conventional truth, they are products. Therefore, the reason of being a product is not established.

If on the basis of this unestablished reason, one makes a contradictory error, that also cannot be established. The verse should say the nature of permanence does not exist. It correctly refutes the existence of the nature of space, etc. as the basis, and incidentally clarifies that the nature of permanence as the dependent [dharmas] does not exist.
If you say that emptiness, etc., do not really exist because their basis does not exist, then the reason is not established, so how can it contradict the self-nature of the property-possessor?
This is also not so, because this reason only refutes other existent things.
There are three kinds of reasons:
1. Reasons that are existent things, such as being a product, etc.;
2. Reasons that are non-existent things, such as not being a product, etc.;
3. Reasons that are both, such as being knowable, etc.
The reason established now only refutes being a product, not saying that there is a separate non-product self-nature.
This reason is absent in the same class, such as form, etc., but is present in the different class, such as tortoise hair, etc. Therefore it contradicts the self-nature of the property-possessor.
Moreover, it is said in verse:
Foolish people falsely discriminate, calling emptiness, etc., permanent.
The treatise says:
Wherever there is seeing, it is all without truth or reality, and wisdom is not pure and clear, so it is called foolish people.

They always dwell in the stage of investigation, seeking and discriminating the natures and characteristics of dharmas. Among them, some have sharp wisdom and insight, but falsely imagine and go beyond the path. Each relying on their own knowledge, they all become arrogant, and they engage in various debates, establishing themselves as teachers and disciples. They have not yet eliminated the net of views based on discrimination. The darkness of ignorance envelops their minds, as if in a dream, and all their objects are false.
Unlike the wisdom in a dream, which imagines space and so forth as eternally abiding and truly existent, which can be relied upon.
Furthermore, some ÅšrÄvaka disciples hold that space and so forth truly exist and eternally abide. Therefore a sÅ«tra says:
Space is without form, invisible, and without obstruction.
On what can it depend?
However, space is manifested through light.
The meaning of this sÅ«tra is that there truly exists space, eternally abiding, without form, invisible, and without obstruction, without any further basis, manifested through light.
Some may have doubts:
Since the Buddha did not say that it has a separate support such as the wind wheel, then space would have no substance or characteristics.
In order to explain this difficulty, it is said that space accommodates and receives resistant light and other forms, manifesting the existence of the cause with real substance and characteristics.
It is also said that space is the support of wind, and that which has no substance and characteristics cannot be a support.
This is also not so, because it is not the meaning of the sÅ«tra.
If it is said that space is a dharma with results, it should have arising and ceasing, because arising and ceasing follow. Its substance would then be impermanent, like form, mind, and so forth.
If it has no arising and ceasing, it should have no substance or characteristics, like the hair of a turtle and so forth.

In order to show that the wind wheel is separate from the aggregation of its own kind and has no separate support like the earth wheel and so forth, the sÅ«tra says that the wind wheel relies on space, but this does not deny the wind wheel.
The support for the arising of the previous moment in the present aggregation of its own kind, therefore it is said.
In order to show that space has no real substance that is the same as or different from the arising of things, because it has no real substance that is permanent and eternal, like the past, etc.
Again, a scripture says that space is formless, invisible, and nonresistant. What does it depend on?

We do not see that there is a real substance that is the same as or different from the arising of things, such as form, feeling, etc., that has no real substance. Also, space is manifested in dependence on light, etc., and is provisionally established in the conventional truth, just as pots, etc., are provisionally established in dependence on form, etc.
Therefore, it is said that space is manifested in dependence on light, but one cannot say that space has a real substance apart from light, etc.
Even though space is established in dependence on shadows and darkness, the eye is obstructed in shadows and darkness.
Or, there may be nothing else to see, and one cannot distinguish whether other things exist or not, and therefore it is not mentioned.

However, it is manifested by the darkness and emptiness of shadows. In bright light, the eye is unobstructed. If one sees without any other obstructing objects, one then relies on this to provisionally establish space. Do not slander space as provisionally nonexistent. It also does not exist. Therefore, it is not said that space does not exist.

Moreover, if space really has a substance and characteristics, and is manifested by various bright lights, it should be like blue and so forth, having form, being visible, having resistance, and having a basis. The sÅ«tras should not say it is formless, invisible, without resistance, and without a basis.
Conventional provisional existence does not have this fault.
Relying on unobstructed form to provisionally establish space, the natures of obstruction and so forth are not mutually corresponding.

Moreover, this space is not included in the four truths. Although it is grasped as really existing, one must certainly admit that it is cognized by discriminating cognition. Excluding the mental consciousness induced by the five sense consciousnesses, the other contaminated indeterminate external-gate discriminating mental consciousness definitely cannot cognize real existent objects.
Therefore, a verse is spoken:
The wise rely on the world, and also do not see this meaning.
The treatise says:

The wise rely on the world and follow the discrimination of consciousness. Although they concentrate their efforts and seek the true meaning of space and so forth, they cannot obtain even the slightest bit, but only see the various images arising from the discrimination based on names, resembling space and so forth.
Next, in order to refute the previously held notion that space and so forth exist substantially and are permanent because they are all-pervading, a verse is spoken:
It is not that a single existent pervades all parts;
Therefore, we know that each part has its own existence.
The treatise says:
Time, space, and the categories of things each have distinctions, and therefore they are called parts.
Space and so forth are associated with those parts, and therefore they are called existents.
It is not that a single existent, which is permanent and real, is universally associated with all parts.
Do not let each of these corresponding parts be universally associated with all.

Therefore, these parts correspond to the various distinctions of the parts, forming innumerable parts. These parts, not depending on other supports, are called space or other kinds of things. Therefore, the meaning of your argument that real, permanent space pervades is not established.

If you say that space, etc. also lack faults because they are established as having spatial divisions through discrimination, this is also not so, because in reality they have no spatial divisions and do not escape the previously mentioned faults.

Vases, etc. should also be established as having spatial divisions. In the ultimate truth, spatial divisions are really non-existent. This reason only exists in dissimilar instances. Since the similar instance is lacking, it contradicts the meaning.

Moreover, the names and expressions of distinctions such as space, etc. are only established based on the combination of the parts, because they are established as having spatial divisions through discrimination.

Just as various names and expressions such as palace are established based solely on the combination of form and so forth, this shows that sounds such as space are established only in terms of conventional objects.

Moreover, if it can be said to have spatial parts, it should not be said to be permanent, all-pervading, and truly existent as the nature of space and so forth, like blue and so forth. In that case, one part of the established proof would not be established.

Next, some people hold the view that time is truly existent and permanent, because they see that when various conditions such as seeds come together, sometimes fruits are produced and sometimes not, and time has functions that expand or contract, causing branches and so forth to flourish or wither accordingly.
The reason given here includes both separation and combination, and therefore it is certain that time truly exists.

But the causes that time depends on are all invisible. Since the causes are not seen, there is no arising. Since there is no arising, one knows there is no ceasing. Since there is no arising and no ceasing, it is said to be permanent.
In order to refute this view, a verse is spoken:
If the substance of dharmas really exists, then the function of contraction and expansion can be obtained.
This samÄdhi arises from others, therefore it is a produced result.
The treatise says:

The establishment of the function of time through contraction and expansion depends on others, therefore this function of time changes according to conditions. If the substance and characteristics have no distinction of acceptance and rejection, then the arising and ceasing of all functions is not established.
Moreover, the function of time changes in dependence on others, just like the color of earth, which is definitely impermanent.
Using this very thing as the same dharma, how can the time that is its basis be allowed to be permanent?
Therefore the good time-keeper says:

The great elements distinguished by being drawn by karmic winds, with their own kind as causes, continue in succession, cycling and passing on from generation to generation, beginning again after ending, with different cold and warm touches according to different conditions, distinguished by different states, called time.
Although time has causes and conditions for arising and ceasing, the similar continuity is concealed and difficult to know. How can it be said that because it is not known, there are no causes, etc.?

Furthermore, there is the view that the substance of time is both permanent and all-pervading, containing immeasurable distinct capacities, and external conditions trigger the arising of various functions, with effects such as sprouts and stems produced according to the functions.
This is also unreasonable. If the substance of time as the basis does not undergo change, how can the capacities based on it be triggered?
We do not see that without the transformation of the basis such as seeds, there can be the capacity to produce sprouts and so forth.
The causes and conditions that trigger this capacity are sufficient to produce the functions of producing sprouts and so forth. Why bother to falsely imagine a useless time?
Moreover, it is said in a verse:
If there is no produced effect, there is no producing cause;
Therefore, all producing causes become the produced effect.
The treatise says:
Dharmas must depend on their own produced effects to have superior substance and function before they can be called causes.
If the produced [effect] does not exist, how can the producing [cause] exist?
Therefore the cause that you claim to be productive must depend on other dharmas to become a cause.
Just as suffering, pleasure, etc., are definitely impermanent. Arenâ€™t the substance and function of causes already present before the effect arises, and the name cause is revealed later?
Just as external conditions have substance and function before the effect arises, and the effect is then said to have conditions.
Time is also like this.
Its substance is eternal and omnipresent, and it contains various powers of production and growth. When the effects arise, its function is then revealed.
Also, an effect that has not yet arisen is also said to have a cause, because it awaits a future effect, just as rice and barley seeds are.

The substance of time that you posit is eternal and omnipresent, and it contains various powers of production and growth. Since the various powers that it contains are admitted to be no different from its substance, the powers should be the same as the substance, each being omnipresent and eternal. In that case, when it produces an effect by generating one effect, it should produce all effects at the one location of that one effect. In this way, cause and effect would become confused.
We establish the capacity as having a definite time and place with regard to the effect that is produced, therefore we do not have this fault.
You establish the capacity as each being permanent and all-pervading, so you should not hastily allow that there is a definite time and place.
If you say that the capacity established by the proponent of the treatise is the same as this fault, this is also not so.

We establish the capacity as existing in dependence on causes and conditions, with various distinctions, not all-pervading and not permanent. In accordance with its own causes and conditions, the various distinctions produce effects that have a definite time and place. Therefore, when producing an effect at one time, it does not produce everything at the place of that one effect. This is why cause and effect do not become confused.
It is not the same as your establishment of time and capacity, both of which are all-pervading and permanent, with no difference before and after. Therefore, only you have the fault of confusion.
Moreover, a verse says:
All dharmas must change before they can become the cause for producing another.
How can this cause of change be said to be permanent?
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

The world agrees that seeds and so on, which are the support of the power of dharmas, must abandon their prior state and take on a later state, and only then can they transform their substance and characteristics and become the cause that produces sprouts and so on.
In this way, the principle of causality is not mistaken. The eternally abiding cause that you posit must also be the same. Only when its substance and characteristics transform can it be a cause.
Since you admit that it transforms, it cannot be eternally abiding.

Isn't it that the world also admits that seeds and so on, in the state when the effect has not yet arisen, have not yet transformed in substance and characteristics, and although they have no activity, they are still called causes?
No. Although the world provisionally speaks in this way, in reality seeds and so on, when about to cease, are only able to produce effects and are then called causes.

At that time, seeds and so on must undergo transformation. Is it that the faculties and objects, which do not cease, are without transformation but have activity in producing the various consciousnesses?
This is also not contradictory, because when about to cease, their substance and characteristics transform and are able to produce the various consciousnesses.
Other masters say:
The faculties and objects are like seeds and sprouts, etc., in the principle of arising and ceasing.
All causes and effects are not simultaneous, so this objection becomes far-fetched.

Moreover, there are other non-Buddhists who hold the view that the natural cause is eternally existent, without arising, ceasing, or changing, and that it naturally serves as the cause to produce all effects.
In order to refute this view, a verse is spoken:
If what was previously non-existent now exists, the natural [cause] is eternally the cause;
Since you admit the natural [cause], the cause is then falsely established.
The treatise states:
If it is held that all dharmas were previously non-existent and now exist, and that there is a natural, eternally abiding cause,
then dharmas should naturally be previously non-existent and now exist. What need is there to falsely establish a natural, eternal cause?
Because you admit that the natural [cause] does not depend on a cause.

Moreover, since the essence of the natural [cause] is eternally without change, when the effect has not yet arisen it is still unable to produce it. When the dharma of the effect arises, it should also be like this, because the before and after are the same. The meaning of the cause is not established.

If you claim that the self-nature is permanent, you lose two things: you lose the acceptance of the necessary conditions that can produce its own effect, and you lose the view that there is a subtle, permanent cause that can produce the coarse effect that is perceived.

If you claim that the self-nature must rely on the assistance of the various conditions with which it is combined in order to be able to produce an effect, and that although the various conditions are different, when they are combined they assist the self-nature in giving rise to a general function,
and that this one general function did not exist before but exists now, therefore the self-nature, although it has always existed,
did not produce the effect before but is able to produce it later, this is also not correct.

If the self-nature is always present, why does it not always cause the various conditions to combine?ğŸ”½Even though the natures of the various conditions are different when they combine, they mutually assist each other in producing a single effect. Apart from this, there is no general function that can be obtained.

Moreover, even though the self-nature is present among the various conditions, when they are combined, it is still unable to produce [the effect], because its nature is no different [from what it was before], just as it was before it was produced.
Moreover, the substance of a permanent dharma is unchanging, so how can it assist?
If you allow that it naturally changes according to conditions like the effect it produces, then it should be impermanent.

Therefore, only impermanent conditions mutually assist each other in producing superior substance and function, different from the previous state, able to produce its effect. The established permanence cannot avoid the previous error.
Next, there are some non-Buddhists who establish a permanent cause, time, which is unchanging and able to produce effects.
This should also be refuted using the example of a contradictory effect. Another verse says:
How can permanence give rise to impermanence?
Cause and effect are not the same, never seen in the world.
The treatise says:
The arising of conditioned phenomena must resemble its cause, therefore it cannot be said to produce effects of a different kind. Isn't it seen that clear water is drawn from a moon-love pearl?
I also do not say that effects arise from causes that are of a different kind, and that all their essential characteristics are the same.

I only say that in the meaning of causes and effects producing each other, the characteristics of non-separation are definitely similar, because in the world we have never seen such causes and effects with different characteristics.
The world commonly sees coarse impermanent effects, all of which arise from impermanent causes. We infer that subtle effects are impermanent.

Just as coarse effects definitely have impermanent causes, therefore form and so forth, which are dharmas with the nature of causes and effects, are definitely not separate from the characteristic of impermanence. In order to determine this meaning,
he further says:
All subtle effects and the form and so forth that are their causes are definitely impermanent, because the effects are impermanent, like the form and so forth that are the causes of coarse effects.
Next, there are those who hold this view:
Space and so forth are all-pervading and permanent.
When conditions come together in one part, sound and so forth arise based on that part.
If sound and so forth arise from the universal support, then the sense organs abiding in the most distant objects should also be cognized.
In order to refute this view, a verse is spoken:
If one part is a cause, and the other parts are not causes,
Then it should be of various kinds, and because of being various, it is impermanent.
The treatise states:

If it is said that when the various conditions such as space come together, one part has a function in producing its own effect, while the other parts have no function and do not produce their own effects,
then space and so forth should be distinguished part by part, because the substance and function of each part are different, and it should be like sound and so forth, definitely impermanent.

Moreover, the substance of this space and so forth is always all-pervading, and can serve as the support for various effects of its own kind. Because it is the support for various characteristics, like brocade and embroidery, it can be proven to be impermanent.
Moreover, as explained above, a permanent dharma is inert and cannot be changed. How can conditions assist it?

The emptiness, etc., that you imagine should also be like this. Since their substance is eternally abiding, even if many conditions come together, how can they generate sound, etc., and their own effects?
Moreover, there are those who hold this view:

When one part arises, it only comes from one substance. The various effects such as the great elements, etc., transform and change, and increase and grow. Since the various effects such as the great elements transform, they are impermanent. The self-nature of one substance does not transform, and therefore it is permanent.
This is also not so, because it contradicts the meaning.

The great elements, etc., all take self-nature as their substance. When the great elements, etc., transform, self-nature should also transform. For this reason, self-nature should be impermanent, because its substance is no different, just like the great elements, etc.

Moreover, this self-nature is all-pervading in substance. When one part transforms, the innumerable other parts should also transform accordingly, because their substance is no different. Then, when one part and one dharma arise, the other parts and other dharmas should all arise together.
In this way, because the entire substance has function, it should be impermanent, just like the effects such as the great elements.
Moreover, the previous verse also refutes this view, because what they imagine to be the most excellent intrinsic nature is composed of three parts, namely sattva, rajas, and tamas.
The first, sattva, has a nature that is clear and bright; the second, rajas, has a nature that is agitated; the third, tamas, has a nature that is dull and obscure.
Each of these three has many characteristics and functions, all of which are things that the self enjoys and uses.

I take thought as my nature. When thought enjoys and uses [these three], the nature of rajas is agitated and causes sattva and the others to give rise to various transforming functions. The three dharmas are harmoniously the same, and following a single part they transform into the great and so forth, and are renamed most excellent.
It is like the great ocean, whose waters are still and calm, but following a single part they are struck by wind and so forth, and transform into various turbulent waves and billows.

In the same way, the intrinsic nature most excellent that is grasped [by the SÄá¹ƒkhyas] transforms into the great and so forth following a single part that has a function, but the other parts are unable and do not transform. This would mean that the intrinsic nature itself would become various.
Because they form various kinds, they must be impermanent, like the effects of the great elements, which are not permanent.

Moreover, each of the three natures has many functions such as clarity, agitation, obscurity, etc. Since the nature and function are considered to be the same substance, according to the functions, the nature should form many substances, because the nature is the most excellent and without distinction.
Then the most excellent substance should also be many, because the substance of the most excellent nature forms many. It should be like the great elements and definitely impermanent.

Furthermore, there is a view that holds that the ultimate atom is permanent and real, and that the combined assistance of the aggregates produces generation, with the self-nature not being diminished while giving rise to various effects.
This is also not so, because the meaning is not established.
If the combination is necessarily with spatial division, since there is spatial division, it is definitely impermanent.
If it is said that the ultimate atom is combined throughout the entire substance without spatial division, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
The verse says:
The round characteristics of the ultimate atom in the cause do not exist in the effect;
Therefore, the ultimate atoms do not universally combine.
The treatise states:

If the ultimate atoms universally combine with their entire substance, because they have no spatial divisions, they do not partially combine. In that case, the atoms should occupy the same place, and the real effect should combine with its own cause everywhere, because there is no separate place, it should also be minute and round.

If so, it should be admitted that all the meanings of sentences transcend the realm cognized by the senses, because the remaining can be known by seeing the basis. This would contradict the worldly and one's own school.

If it is said that although the real effect combines with its own cause with its entire substance and has no separate place, however, by the power of the accumulation of quantity and virtue, it is allowed that the real effect can also be seen, that is to say, although the real effect has no place to abide and no spatial divisions,
However, by the excellence of the accumulation of quantity and virtue, it causes the real basis to appear large although not large, and the spatial divisions are clearly visible.
This is just words, completely without real meaning.
I previously criticized you:
The real fruit that is produced is not separate from the atoms, and therefore it should be like the atoms in exceeding the objects of the senses.
You cannot save this position, so why bother with other words?

If the real substance that is the support appears in this way, it should abandon its real substance and be the same as that which it supports. Since it becomes the characteristics of another, it should abandon its own characteristics.

It also cannot be said that it is like crystal, which does not abandon its previous characteristics but manifests other characteristics, because its substance is impermanent and different before and after.
If this is the same as that, it should abandon its real substance.
The virtues are based on the real, and when the real substance is nonexistent, the virtues also do not exist.
When there is no real and no virtues, who manifests and who has characteristics?
Therefore it cannot be said that the real fruit that is produced does not abandon its own characteristics but manifests the characteristics of another.
In this way, only the virtues would be visible, and all the real natures would exceed the objects of the senses. This also contradicts your own established position.
Next, some say that the atoms have form and substance, because they mutually obstruct each other, and therefore their locations are not the same.
In this case, although the atoms are adjacent, their locations are still separate, so they should not combine.
If you admit they combine, then their locations are either the same or different. This contradicts your own tenets, and there is the fault of having parts.

Some say that atoms are born in different locations. Although they are without interval, they do not touch each other. Each occupies a single direction, avoiding each other and abiding. The differences in accumulation seem to have spatial parts. Without interval, they are born in place, seeming to have flowing and turning. The moments before and after continue in succession, with cause and effect, neither annihilated nor eternal.
In order to refute them further, another verse is spoken:
Since it is not admitted that other [atoms] exist in the location of one atom,
Therefore one should not admit that cause and effect are of equal measure.
The treatise states:
In this way, the characteristics of atoms that have been explained are still unable to avoid the fault of having spatial parts.
Why is this?
A verse says:
If an atom has an eastern direction, it must also have an eastern part;
If the atom has parts, how can it be an atom?
The treatise states:

These atoms, since they have material obstruction, when the sun just rises and its light touches them, the light and shadow appear on both sides of the east and west, following the moving light and shadow.
Since the place where the light is received and the shadow is emitted is different, it is known that the atom definitely has spatial division.
Since it has spatial division, it loses being an atom. In this way, the atom can be analyzed and should be like coarse objects, not being real or permanent.
This contradicts the tenet of your treatise, which states that the atom has no spatial division, is permanently existent, and creates the myriad things of the world.

Furthermore, the atom that is grasped definitely has spatial division because it is the basis of movement, like the mover itself. Wherever one travels, there must be spatial division. If there is no spatial division, then there is nowhere to go.
Why is this?
The verse states:
One must take the front and abandon the back in order to speak of movement.
The treatise states:
The joy of progress is called taking the former, and the disgust of regression is called abandoning the latter.
One must rely on the distinction of the former and latter to give rise to the function of taking and abandoning, which is then called activity.
Apart from the activity of distinction, we have never seen it.
Since the ultimate atom is the basis of activity, we know that the ultimate atom definitely has distinction.
If there is no distinction in the activity of the object of activity, then one should deny that the active person exists.
Therefore, a verse says:
If these two are non-existent, the active person should not exist.
The treatise says:

Relying on the distinction of the former and latter to give rise to the function of taking and abandoning, if distinction does not exist, the function should also not exist. If so, although active, one should be like something unmoving.
If you deny the activity of the object of activity, then the active person as the basis also does not exist. Grasping these ultimate atoms, one then falls into wrong views.
Moreover, if the ultimate atoms have no activity, then they cannot produce effects with distinction.

If there is a result with spatial parts that is not produced, then the divine eye also sees nothing. Then all the established meanings would transcend the objects of the senses and be completely cut off from words. How can one establish the distinctions of meanings oneself?

Moreover, if one grasps the extreme atom as having no beginning, middle, or end, then the pure eye faculty would also not be able to see it, and it would be completely nonexistent, like a flower in the sky.
In order to illustrate this meaning, a verse is spoken:
The extreme atom has no initial part, and the middle and final parts also do not exist;
Then all eyes would be unable to see it.
The treatise states:

If one grasps the extreme atom as being permanent and unitary, without the three temporal divisions of arising, abiding, and ceasing, and without the three spatial divisions of front, middle, and rear, it should be completely unreal, like a flower in the sky.

Then the extreme atom would transcend the objects of the senses and not be seen by any eye. It would be completely unobtainable when examined by oneself or others. Therefore, it should not be considered to be truly existent.

Here, it directly refutes the extreme subtle particles grasped by non-Buddhists as being permanent and partless, transcending the objects of the senses and unseen by the eye, and also reveals that extreme subtle particles are impermanent and have parts, not transcending the objects of the senses and seen by the pure eye.

Furthermore, in order to refute the cause and effect of extreme subtle particles occupying the same place, and to reveal that the substance of the cause is definitely impermanent, therefore it says in the verse:
If the cause is destroyed by the effect, then the cause is impermanent;
Or it may be that the effect and cause have two different substances and do not occupy the same place.
The treatise states:
When other obstructed objects press against an obstructed object, if it does not move from its place it will certainly be transformed and destroyed.

In this way, the extreme subtle particles of the effect invade and press against it, either mutually accepting each other and occupying the same place with different substances, like a fine stream irrigating a pile of coarse sand;
Or else entering into it and causing it to transform, like a wonderful medicinal juice poured into red molten copper.

If you admit the former, then there are parts. Since they mutually enter each other, the parts are separated, just as separated things do not produce effects together. Then there would be no coarse things at all.
Moreover, if they are like that and have subtle parts, then they should be impermanent like that.
If you admit the latter, you yourself say that atoms have substance and change. Why wait for questioning and difficulty?

If you do not admit either, you should admit that atoms mutually obstruct each other, and cause and effect are in separate places, because obstructed things cannot be in the same place, just like non-cause and effect obstructed things.
Moreover, it is said in verse:
One does not see any dharmas that are permanent and yet have resistance;
Therefore atoms are permanent, but the Buddhas have never said so.
The treatise says:
It is presently seen that things like stone obstruct other things in their own place. Since they are impermanent, atoms are also like this. How can they be permanent?
Obstruction and permanence are mutually contradictory, and it is unreasonable for two dharmas to have the same substance.
There is another separate explanation:
The cause of the arising of change and destruction through the combination of other objects is called obstruction.
Otherwise, all atoms would have obstruction, and obstruction would clearly prove impermanence.

If it is said that atoms obstruct other objects, but others do not fully accept this, therefore it is necessary to separately establish the cause of the arising of change and destruction through the combination of other objects, and infer that atoms are impermanent, then it should only be possible to prove the nature of atoms as definitely impermanent by the meaning of being able to produce them. Why is it said to be obstruction in the verse?
Therefore, we know that this statement means having obstruction.
Although it is not fully accepted, the meaning of the cause is established because they accept that atoms obstruct other objects.

Since atoms are refuted, space is also destroyed. The cause of atoms is the proof of the true existence of space. Since atoms do not exist, the effect does not exist. On what basis is space established as real and permanent?
Moreover, direction is not established in dependence on conditions, it is provisionally established as existing, not real and not permanent.
For the above reasons, the ultimate atom is permanent. The Buddha has never said that all conditioned phenomena are impermanent.

Only our Great Master, the Sole Awakened One, has unobstructed knowledge and insight into all realms. What he says is unmistaken, truly called the TathÄgata. He pities those in wrong paths who are unable to believe and return to the impermanence of all conditioned phenomena. Indeed, the Buddha said that the unconditioned is not a conditioned phenomenon. How can it be abandoned as permanent?
However, the permanence established has no more than two kinds:
One is that which has function, the other is that which has no function.
If it has function, it is not called unconditioned. If it has no function, it is merely a nominal concept.
Therefore a sutra says:
The five dharmas of going, coming, self, space, and nirvana, are merely nominal concepts, without any real meaning.
